questions.name: instructions3
questions.html: Once you have finalized your answers from the previous set of questions, the correct definitions/context will be shown below.

questions.name: questionvis
questions.title: Have you selected your final answers from the previous set of questions?

questions.name: privacypolicyre
questions.title: Please indicate your thoughts on the following terms with their correct definitions/context given

columns.name: col1
choices: The term is appropriate for its meaning.
The term is appropriate but should be defined within the document if it is used.
The term is vague, misleading, or otherwise confusing and can be reworded.

columns.name: reword
columns.title: Type any term(s) that you think could be more appropriate or less confusing. This section is not required.

rows: A "privacy policy" is a legal document that says how users' data will be collected and used.
"Keys" describe information that is necessary to read/decode messages.
Websites are still able to track you if you send a "Do Not Track request"
A company storing information about you using "browser web storage" means the information is stored on your machine or device.
A company storing information about you using "local storage" also means the information is stored on your machine or device.
"Metadata" describes data about data or files (including size, time, location, message recipient(s), uploader(s))
A company using a "cryptographic hash" means they store information that allows them to check your password, but your password is not stored in plain text.
A "pixel tag" is a way to monitor which sites users visit using a small image.
A "web beacon" is also a way to monitor which sites users visit using a small image.
"Persistent cookies" can be manually deleted and have experation dates.
"Incognito mode"/"private browsing" does not make you anonymous on the internet. The data is stored on machines or servers belonging to either the websites browsed or third parties.
"De-identified information" can be tied to you as an individual.
"Anonymized information" can also be tied to you as an individual.
